content.raw:
hi Andrew, thanks for opening the discussion of an interesting topic. 

This general purpose library started as a replacement for a custom transport library used in Gazebo. The Gazebo transport library uses Boost.Asio and it has been successfully working quite a while. So, it's a fact that Boost.Asio is a good option for a transport library.

ZMQ offers publish/subscribe and request/response sockets (among others) which mimics really well the type of interface that we want to expose to the users. Boost.Asio offers a more classic approach based on [a]synchronous send/receive primitives. The main reason for choosing ZMQ is to minimize as much as possible custom code for implementing pub/sub and request/response communications.

There are other reasons such as:

  * Authentication and encryption: We haven't explored that road yet but CurveZMQ has built-in capabilities for it.
  * Small dependency list compared with Boost.Asio. 

       * libasio-dev:  libboost-date-time-dev, libboost-dev, libboost-date-time1.54-dev, libboost-date-time1.54.0, libboost-serialization1.54-dev, libboost1.54-dev, libboost-serialization1.54.0, libboost1.54-dev.
       * libzmq3-dev: libzmq3, libpgm-5.1-0.

A reference comparing DDS, ZMQ and Boost.Asio:
http://mnb.ociweb.com/mnb/MiddlewareNewsBrief-201004.html

We're also aware of the ZMQ limitations, e.g., the lack of an UDP transport alternative.
content.html:
hi Andrew, thanks for opening the discussion of an interesting topic.

This general purpose library started as a replacement for a custom transport library used in Gazebo. The Gazebo transport library uses Boost.Asio and it has been successfully working quite a while. So, it's a fact that Boost.Asio is a good option for a transport library.

ZMQ offers publish/subscribe and request/response sockets (among others) which mimics really well the type of interface that we want to expose to the users. Boost.Asio offers a more classic approach based on [a]synchronous send/receive primitives. The main reason for choosing ZMQ is to minimize as much as possible custom code for implementing pub/sub and request/response communications.

There are other reasons such as:

  • Authentication and encryption: We haven't explored that road yet but CurveZMQ has built-in capabilities for it.

  • Small dependency list compared with Boost.Asio.

    • libasio-dev: libboost-date-time-dev, libboost-dev, libboost-date-time1.54-dev, libboost-date-time1.54.0, libboost-serialization1.54-dev, libboost1.54-dev, libboost-serialization1.54.0, libboost1.54-dev.
    • libzmq3-dev: libzmq3, libpgm-5.1-0.

A reference comparing DDS, ZMQ and Boost.Asio: http://mnb.ociweb.com/mnb/MiddlewareNewsBrief-201004.html

We're also aware of the ZMQ limitations, e.g., the lack of an UDP transport alternative.

content.raw:
I understand your motivation for a pub-sub system and agree that there are many nice aspects of pub-sub. I forgot to explain in more detail that ZeroMQ is implemented using asio and that is a first class citizen of ZeroMQ. The linked [azmq](https://github.com/zeromq/azmq) provides a full implementation of ZeroMQ with asio style programming. 

You are accurate when you mention Boost.asio's dependencies, so fortunately [pure asio](http://think-async.com/Asio/) has no external dependencies thus I'd advise that if it is possible to use azmq with pure asio. I also wanted to mention that Asio is expected to eventually becomes part of the C++ Standard Library. When that comes to pass it should be minimally difficult to switch over and drop the asio dependency and just use the functionality provided by the standard library, allowing a dependency to be dropped in the future.

I've used DDS before and it was a poor experience. Regarding ZeroMQ, I've heard from other talented developers for whom I have the utmost respect and they were very happy overall with the framework. I concur with your decision that ZeroMQ is the way to go. I'd also like to submit the asio implementation for consideration, since asio style programming provides a number of useful tools and design advantages.

I should also add that I posted the incorrect link when referring to the [atomic-sleep problem](https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~410-f09/lectures/L10a_Synch.pdf). This one is corrected and I've corrected the original link.
content.html:
I understand your motivation for a pub-sub system and agree that there are many nice aspects of pub-sub. I forgot to explain in more detail that ZeroMQ is implemented using asio and that is a first class citizen of ZeroMQ. The linked azmq provides a full implementation of ZeroMQ with asio style programming.

You are accurate when you mention Boost.asio's dependencies, so fortunately pure asio has no external dependencies thus I'd advise that if it is possible to use azmq with pure asio. I also wanted to mention that Asio is expected to eventually becomes part of the C++ Standard Library. When that comes to pass it should be minimally difficult to switch over and drop the asio dependency and just use the functionality provided by the standard library, allowing a dependency to be dropped in the future.

I've used DDS before and it was a poor experience. Regarding ZeroMQ, I've heard from other talented developers for whom I have the utmost respect and they were very happy overall with the framework. I concur with your decision that ZeroMQ is the way to go. I'd also like to submit the asio implementation for consideration, since asio style programming provides a number of useful tools and design advantages.

I should also add that I posted the incorrect link when referring to the atomic-sleep problem. This one is corrected and I've corrected the original link.

content.raw: I also didn't realize that gazebo currently uses boost.asio under the hood, that is great!
content.html: I also didn't realize that gazebo currently uses boost.asio under the hood, that is great!

content.raw: Could you elaborate on the atomic-sleep problem? If you are referring to the tests, I agree that we should find a better mechanism to synchronize events happening in different processes.
content.html: Could you elaborate on the atomic-sleep problem? If you are referring to the tests, I agree that we should find a better mechanism to synchronize events happening in different processes.

content.raw: Essentially, sleeping to wait for some other task to complete will always sleep for the wrong amount of time. Instead, the other task should trigger a signal to release the sleeping thread. Also, even if the "task" is to wake up at a set time, say, every second, sleeping for 1 second, doing something, then sleeping for a second will cause the time to drift relative to the desired frequency of running once a second. Thus, it is better to set a deadline_timer to make a call one second from the start time, then advance it another one second relative to the start time. That way there won't be any drift.
content.html: Essentially, sleeping to wait for some other task to complete will always sleep for the wrong amount of time. Instead, the other task should trigger a signal to release the sleeping thread. Also, even if the "task" is to wake up at a set time, say, every second, sleeping for 1 second, doing something, then sleeping for a second will cause the time to drift relative to the desired frequency of running once a second. Thus, it is better to set a deadline_timer to make a call one second from the start time, then advance it another one second relative to the start time. That way there won't be any drift.

content.raw:
We don't use sleep's as a synchronization primitive between threads. When we want to "sleep" for a certain amount of time until an event occurs we use a condition variable (happily included in C++11). We don't have any boost dependency so far, so we cannot use `deadline_timer`.

I'm describing the core library, the tests should be improved with better mechanisms to notify events between threads/processes.
content.html:
We don't use sleep's as a synchronization primitive between threads. When we want to "sleep" for a certain amount of time until an event occurs we use a condition variable (happily included in C++11). We don't have any boost dependency so far, so we cannot use deadline_timer.

I'm describing the core library, the tests should be improved with better mechanisms to notify events between threads/processes.

content.raw: We are sticking with zeromq for the foreseeable future.
